I said it six months ago, and I‚Äôll say it again: We know this is a crisis. We must do something about it. It's time to deliver the emergency supplemental funding @POTUS requested. pic.twitter.com/FjD7Dxx2md

We do not have a choice but to get this emergency supplemental done. It‚Äôs the only choice we have from a humanitarian perspective, and it‚Äôs the only choice we have from a border security perspective. pic.twitter.com/qduxQWSTHL
But they have stepped up to address a national need.  And it is past time we stepped up for them and these families and children in need.

The men and women of @DHSgov who work our border and are trying to process this influx of people are doing tremendous work.  It is stressful, it is hard, and in many cases it is not the mission they signed up for when they joined the Department of Homeland Security.

It was 103 degrees this past weekend in McAllen, Texas, which is the epicenter of this crisis.  And it is getting hotter. I hate to think what the situation will look like this summer if we fail to act.

If we fail, @DHSgov will be faced with a choice: it will either have to stop its efforts to improve these brutal conditions on our border or it will have to raid other agencies vital to our national security.

As Chair of the Approps Cmte. Subcommittee on Homeland Security, I will repeat again: we do not have a choice but to get this supplemental done.  It‚Äôs the only choice we have from a humanitarian perspective. It‚Äôs the only choice we have from a border security perspective.
BUT there is not much that can be done to improve the situation UNLESS we provide the resources to deal with this crisis.
People are upset about seeing pictures of people sleeping on concrete floors under mylar blankets.  I‚Äôve been to these facilities, and, yes, it will absolutely break your heart to see it.

Today we have significantly more people crossing our southern border ‚Äì and because of who they are travelling with and where they are travelling from ‚Äì each of those people causes significantly more strain on our system.
Unlike folks from Mexico, these migrants cannot just be sent back home under U.S. law.  They remain in the U.S., often for months or even years, as their cases work their way through the system.

Today, we are seeing families ‚Äì not just adults.  Last month, nearly 64% of those who crossed our border illegally did so as members of a family unit, coming namely from Guatemala, El Salvador, and Honduras.

Twenty years ago, the vast majority of those crossing our border illegally were adult men from Mexico. In fact, in FY 2000, 98% of those caught at our border were Mexican.  Under U.S. law, folks from Mexico can be immediately returned home by our Border Patrol.
In the month of May alone, @CBP apprehended a population that is larger than the populations of Charleston, Huntington, and Morgantown ‚Äì COMBINED.

For months, administration officials have been telling us the humanitarian & security crisis at the border is at a breaking point. It‚Äôs only getting worse. Enough is enough.
